title: 1969-D
statement: D. Shop Gametime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputAlice and Bob are playing a game in the shop. There are $$$n$$$ items in the shop; each item has two parameters: $$$a_i$$$ (item price for Alice) and $$$b_i$$$ (item price for Bob).Alice wants to choose a subset (possibly empty) of items and buy them. After that, Bob does the following:if Alice bought less than $$$k$$$ items, Bob can take all of them for free;otherwise, he will take $$$k$$$ items for free that Alice bought (Bob chooses which $$$k$$$ items it will be), and for the rest of the chosen items, Bob will buy them from Alice and pay $$$b_i$$$ for the $$$i$$$-th item.Alice's profit is equal to $$$\\sum\\limits_{i \\in S} b_i - \\sum\\limits_{j \\in T} a_j$$$, where $$$S$$$ is the set of items Bob buys from Alice, and $$$T$$$ is the set of items Alice buys from the shop. In other words, Alice's profit is the difference between the amount Bob pays her and the amount she spends buying the items.Alice wants to maximize her profit, Bob wants to minimize Alice's profit. Your task is to calculate Alice's profit if both Alice and Bob act optimally.InputThe first line contains a single integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 10^4$$$) — the number of test cases.The first line of each test case contains two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$k$$$ ($$$1 \\le n \\le 2 \\cdot 10^5$$$; $$$0 \\le k \\le n$$$).The second line contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, \\dots, a_n$$$ ($$$1 \\le a_i \\le 10^9$$$).The third line contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$b_1, b_2, \\dots, b_n$$$ ($$$1 \\le b_i \\le 10^9$$$).Additional constraint on the input: the sum of $$$n$$$ over all test cases doesn't exceed $$$2 \\cdot 10^5$$$.OutputFor each test case, print a single integer — Alice's profit if both Alice and Bob act optimally.ExampleInput42 02 11 24 11 2 1 43 3 2 34 22 1 1 14 2 3 26 21 3 4 9 1 37 6 8 10 6 8Output1 1 0 7NoteIn the first test case, Alice should buy the $$$2$$$-nd item and sell it to Bob, so her profit is $$$2 - 1 = 1$$$.In the second test case, Alice should buy the $$$1$$$-st, the $$$2$$$-nd and the $$$3$$$-rd item; then Bob takes the $$$1$$$-st item for free and pays for the $$$2$$$-nd and the $$$3$$$-rd item. Alice's profit is $$$(3+2) - (1+2+1) = 1$$$. Bob could take $$$2$$$-nd item for free instead; this does not change Alice's profit. Bob won't take the $$$3$$$-rd item for free, since this would lead to a profit of $$$2$$$.

There are $n$ items, each with a price for Alice ($a_i$) and a price for Bob ($b_i$). Alice wants to buy some items and sell them to Bob for a profit. Bob has a special rule:

* If Alice buys less than $k$ items, Bob can take all of them for free.
* If Alice buys $k$ or more items, Bob takes $k$ items for free and pays for the rest.

Alice's profit is the total amount Bob pays her minus the total amount she spends buying items.

Find Alice's maximum profit if both Alice and Bob act strategically. 

Input:

* $t$: the number of test cases
* For each test case:
    * $n$: the number of items
    * $k$: the special rule threshold
    * $a_1, a_2, ..., a_n$: the prices for Alice
    * $b_1, b_2, ..., b_n$: the prices for Bob

Output:

* For each test case, print Alice's maximum profit.

You are given a set of items, each with two prices: one for you and one for another person. You can choose some items to buy. The other person can then take some of your items for free, up to a certain limit. For any items they don't take for free, they will buy them from you at their price. Your goal is to find the maximum profit you can make.
